At 1h50s20s, of v=hMKqPgWJYr8, Michael S. Neiberg claims that "You can walk around #Berlin and really have no idea that there was a First World War. There is no outdoor marker at all to it".

All eyes on the four The Linke seats in Eat Berlin. The Linke will need to win at least 2 of them to continue in parliament (it looks like they just missed the 5% threshold). I expect they will keep at least Berlin-Treptow ‚Äì K√∂penick and Berlin-Marzahn ‚Äì Hellersdorf.

Die Linke is winning only 2 out of the 4 Berlin single-member constituencies they hold: Lichtenberg and Treptow-Kopenick. They're behind in Pankow and Marzahn-Hellersdorf. The article goes on about how she was about "art and not politics."

Yeah, about that...

"For the indoor scenes, filmed in Berlin-Babelsberg in 1942, Riefenstahl used as extras at least 66 Roma and Sinti inmates, virtually all males, from the Berlin-Marzahn camp for Gypsies"

Like the Jews, they were discriminated against for centuries and still are today.

In preparation for the 1936 Berlin summer Olympic Games, the city of Berlin was cleared of all Roma and Sinti men, women and children, many of them taken to the Berlin-Marzahn concentration camp. https://t.co/6l9bNLnV7c

Today the 85th commemoration of the Berlin-Marzahn deportation took place.During the #Holocaust,Sinti and Roma were forced to live in camps in Marzahn as Nazi-Germany hosted the #Olympics.Otto Rosenberg was part of the people who lived there and an Auschwitz survivor. https://t.co/tsK5fjK0vP

Drove today with the bicycle through Berlin. Although I was born here, it is always interesting, how different the districts are. Drove today through Marzahn-Hellersdorf and was again surprised of the difference of small one family housings and the big living complexes.

@zarathustra_us @gracerector Indeed. One of the strangest experiences of my year in Kaulsdorf, East Berlin in 1991-2 was pulling into a gas station on the Frankfurter Allee -- and seeing a Russian major in full uniform filling up his car at the other pump. Which was, of course, perfectly normal.

@zarathustra_us I can assure you my views about Germany are not based on Wikipedia. I am married to a German, have spent about six years living there, including one year in East Berlin shortly after the Wende. And not in Mitte either: Kaulsdorf. But if you can point to literature, I'm all eyes.

@PortalBookshop in east berlin in the 70s, there was a trans woman called Charlotte von Mahlsdorf who had this huge house and basically ran a queer support group there. it essentially got shut down by the stasi in 1978 but she was the most well known trans woman in the area :)

This museum was founded by Charlotte Von Mahlsdorf (a transgender woman ‚Äì according to eng Wikipedia) and housed a collection of furniture and objects found in old bombed houses. In the 70s it became a meeting point for Berlin's LGBT community. https://t.co/sGc07NUdfT
